newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.AFRICA PLANS RESCUE BID FOR BANKRUPT COUNCILS.
newsitem.headline: S.AFRICA PLANS RESCUE BID FOR BANKRUPT COUNCILS.

text.p: The South African government has implemented a package to rescue town councils pushed into the red by costs of the transition to democracy and politically motivated boycotts dating from the apartheid years.
Provincial Affairs Minister Mohammed Valli Moosa told parliament that councils were owed a total of 5.6 billion rand ($1.23 billion) in service charges at the end of June.
He said Gauteng, which includes the industrial region around Johannesburg, was worst off with bad debts of 2.9 billion rand, followed by KwaZulu-Natal with 826 million rand outstanding.
The department said in a report to parliament's provincial affairs committee that Eskom, the state-owned power utility, was owed 938 million rand.

"Effectively, local authorities are starting to use Eskom as an overdraft facility," the department said, adding that 48 of the country's 800 municipalities did not have cash reserves to pay their electricity bills.
"Some 95 local authorities were identified with insufficient cash to cover one month's manpower bill," the department said.
The report said some councils were structurally able to bill fewer than 75 percent of their clients, adding: "Only 69 percent of all accounts rendered are paid on a regular basis."
The backlog arises partly out of an apartheid-era rent and service charge boycott endorsed by the African national Congress as a weapon against white rule.
After several years of not paying, clients are resisting efforts by the ANC, now in power for over two and half years, to re-establish a culture of payment.
Even some elected ANC councillors and one deputy minister are behind in their service payments to local authorities.
The department's report stressed the need for councillors to help establish payment discipline in their areas.
"Major progress has been made in the transition to local democracy," the report said.
"There have, however, been significant costs associated with the transition and many local authorities have inherited new areas which were in a state of virtual financial collapse."
The department said "Project Liquidity" was instituted to assess the scale of the problem and to set up mechanisms to help councils unable to pay their debts.
Officials were unable to give any immediate estimate of the cost of the project and the scheme to keep ailing municipalities afloat.
